post.subject: Re: Please post your questions here
post.message: It is not a question of whether the gain is programmatically or manually changed.  Instead, it is a question of whether the change is given in absolute form or incremental form.  If it is the former, any mistakes in the initial values may affect drastically, while it may not be a serious problem in the case of the latter.

post.subject: Slide 13 Integral and derivative approximations of PID controller
post.message:

In slide 13, we are using the trapezoidal approximation to discretise the I mode and we are using the backward difference approximation to discretise the D mode. post.subject: Re: Cascade Control
post.message:
The two situtations are different.  The bumpless controller that I am talking about will remove the bumps that arise out of possible book keeping mistakes while going from one control mode (say manual) to another (say automatic). 

What you are talking about has to do with the situation when no mistake in book keeping is made.

You should carry out the calculations and check them out for yourself.

post.subject: Re: Please post your questions here
post.message:
You should have stated the slide number.  My answer would have been slightly different, depending on the slide number.

We start off by saying that we will give the sudden change in the reference signal only to the integral mode - giving sudden change to the derivative and proportional modes can result in big changes in the error and hence in the control effort.  Thus, the integral mode only comes in the forward path.  The other modes are weighted by a small number in the forward path.

The proportional mode and the derivative mode can be given the plant output, however, as it does not have sudden changes.  Thus, the feedback path can have the proportional and the derivative modes.

post.subject: Re: slide 25

post.subject: Re: Please post your questions here
post.message:
• Trapezoidal approximation is more correct than forward or backward approximation.
  • Unfortunately, if you use it in the derivative mode, there are oscillations, as it is a high pass filter.
  • So, we go for another implementation, even if it is less approximate.

I explained in the last class how the filtering action changes depending on the pole, zero locations.  From your question, I believe that you did not attend it.  You may want to read section 5.4.1 in the book.

There is no hard and fast rule that tells which approximation is to be used.

post.subject: Re: Please post your questions here
post.message:
Actually, what I have written in the slide is only partially correct, as the bumpless action can be recovered.

The reason for making that statement is that when you multiply the terms on the left hand side, we lose the $$\Delta u$$ form.

How do we recover the bumpless action?  Let $$u_1 = (1+r_1z^{-1})u$$.  Then, the left hand side can be written as $$\Delta u_1$$, which is once again in the difference form!

post.subject: Re: About integral term
post.message: The difference between desired position and actual position. In the beginning the tracking error is maximum. So if we apply the integration term from the beginning it would create much more large integral term compared to that of proportional and differential. So we can apply itegration of the error after the error has reached below some threshold and not from the beginning so as to reduce steady state offset.
